notes.title: Introduction to Euclid's Division Lemma
points: For any two positive integers 'a' and 'b', there exist unique integers 'q' and 'r' such that a = bq + r, where 0 ≤ r < b
If r = 0, then b is a factor of a
Used to find the HCF of two numbers

notes.title: Applications
points: Finding HCF using division method
Proving mathematical theorems
Used in modular arithmetic

formulas.title: Euclid's Division Algorithm
formulas.formula: a = bq + r, where 0 ≤ r < b
formulas.explanation: a = dividend, b = divisor, q = quotient, r = remainder

realworld.title: Distributing Objects Equally
realworld.description: When distributing 'a' objects among 'b' people, each gets 'q' objects with 'r' remaining

notes.title: Prime Factorization
points: Every composite number can be expressed as a product of primes
This factorization is unique, apart from the order of prime factors
Also known as Unique Factorization Theorem

notes.title: Applications
points: Finding HCF and LCM of numbers
Determining if a number is rational or irrational
Used in cryptography

formulas.title: Prime Factorization
formulas.formula: n = p₁^a × p₂^b × p₃^c × ...
formulas.explanation: Where p₁, p₂, p₃ are prime numbers and a, b, c are their respective powers

realworld.title: Cryptography
realworld.description: Used in RSA encryption where security relies on the difficulty of factoring large numbers

notes.title: HCF (Highest Common Factor)
points: Largest number that divides each of the given numbers without leaving a remainder
Also called Greatest Common Divisor (GCD)
Can be found using prime factorization or Euclid's algorithm

notes.title: LCM (Least Common Multiple)
points: Smallest number that is a multiple of each of the given numbers
Useful in problems involving time, work, and synchronization

formulas.title: Relationship between HCF and LCM
formulas.formula: HCF(a,b) × LCM(a,b) = a × b
formulas.explanation: For any two positive integers a and b, the product of HCF and LCM equals the product of the numbers

realworld.title: Synchronizing Traffic Lights
realworld.description: Used to determine when multiple traffic lights will turn green simultaneously

notes.title: Understanding Irrational Numbers
points: Numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of integers
Their decimal expansion is non-terminating and non-recurring
Examples include √2, π, e

notes.title: Properties
points: The sum or difference of a rational and an irrational number is irrational
The product of a non-zero rational number and an irrational number is irrational
The sum, difference, product, and quotient of two irrational numbers can be rational or irrational

formulas.title: Proof that √2 is irrational
formulas.formula: Assume √2 is rational → √2 = p/q → 2 = p²/q² → 2q² = p²
formulas.explanation: This leads to a contradiction as it implies p² and hence p is even, but then q must also be even, contradicting our assumption that p/q is in simplest form

realworld.title: Diagonals of a Square
realworld.description: The diagonal of a unit square is √2 units long, an irrational number

notes.title: Understanding Zeros of a Polynomial
points: A zero of a polynomial p(x) is a value 'a' such that p(a) = 0
The number of zeros of a polynomial is equal to its degree
A polynomial of degree 'n' can have at most 'n' real zeros
The graph of a polynomial can cross or touch the x-axis at its zeros

notes.title: Finding Zeros
points: For linear polynomial ax + b, zero is x = -b/a
For quadratic polynomials, use factorization or quadratic formula
For higher degree polynomials, use factor theorem and synthetic division

formulas.title: Quadratic Formula
formulas.formula: For ax² + bx + c = 0, zeros are x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / (2a)
formulas.explanation: This formula gives the roots of any quadratic equation

formulas.title: Factor Theorem
formulas.formula: (x - a) is a factor of p(x) if and only if p(a) = 0
formulas.explanation: Helps in factorizing polynomials and finding their zeros

realworld.title: Projectile Motion
realworld.description: The zeros of the height-time polynomial in projectile motion give the time when the object is at ground level

realworld.title: Profit Analysis
realworld.description: In business, the zeros of the profit function represent the break-even points where revenue equals cost

notes.title: For Quadratic Polynomials
points: Sum of zeros (α + β) = -b/a
Product of zeros (α × β) = c/a
Polynomial can be written as: x² - (α+β)x + αβ = 0

notes.title: For Cubic Polynomials
points: Sum of zeros (α + β + γ) = -b/a
Sum of product of zeros two at a time (αβ + βγ + γα) = c/a
Product of zeros (αβγ) = -d/a

formulas.title: Quadratic Polynomial Formula
formulas.formula: If α and β are zeros, then p(x) = x² - (α+β)x + αβ
formulas.explanation: This helps in forming a quadratic equation when zeros are known

formulas.title: Cubic Polynomial Formula
formulas.formula: If α, β, γ are zeros, then p(x) = x³ - (α+β+γ)x² + (αβ+βγ+γα)x - αβγ
formulas.explanation: Helps in forming cubic equations from known roots

realworld.title: Engineering Design
realworld.description: In control systems, the relationship between coefficients and roots determines system stability

realworld.title: Economics
realworld.description: The relationship between cost, volume, and profit can be modeled using polynomial equations

notes.title: Graph Characteristics
points: The graph of a polynomial of degree n has at most (n-1) turning points
The end behavior depends on the leading coefficient and degree
The graph crosses the x-axis at real zeros with odd multiplicity
The graph touches and turns around at real zeros with even multiplicity

notes.title: Types of Graphs
points: Linear: Straight line graph (degree 1)
Quadratic: Parabola (degree 2)
Cubic: S-shaped curve (degree 3)
Quartic: W or M shaped (degree 4)

formulas.title: Vertex Form of Quadratic
formulas.formula: y = a(x - h)² + k, where (h,k) is the vertex
formulas.explanation: Useful for graphing parabolas by identifying key points

formulas.title: Point of Inflection
formulas.formula: For cubic f(x), solve f''(x) = 0
formulas.explanation: The point where the curve changes concavity

realworld.title: Bridge Design
realworld.description: The shape of suspension bridge cables follows a parabolic curve, a type of polynomial graph

realworld.title: Market Analysis
realworld.description: Polynomial regression is used to model and predict trends in stock market data

realworld.title: Physics
realworld.description: The path of a projectile follows a parabolic trajectory, which is a quadratic polynomial

notes.title: Understanding Graphical Solution
points: A pair of linear equations in two variables can be represented graphically as two straight lines
The point of intersection represents the solution (x, y) that satisfies both equations
Three possibilities exist: one solution (intersecting lines), no solution (parallel lines), or infinitely many solutions (coincident lines)
The solution is consistent if lines intersect or coincide, inconsistent if parallel

notes.title: Steps to Solve Graphically
points: Convert each equation to slope-intercept form (y = mx + b)
Find at least two points for each line by assigning values to x
Plot the points and draw the lines on graph paper
The intersection point gives the solution (x, y)

formulas.title: Standard Form
formulas.formula: a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0
formulas.explanation: General form of a pair of linear equations in two variables

formulas.title: Consistency Conditions
formulas.formula: a₁/a₂ ≠ b₁/b₂ (unique solution), a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ = c₁/c₂ (infinite solutions), a₁/a₂ = b₁/b₂ ≠ c₁/c₂ (no solution)
formulas.explanation: Determines the nature of solutions without graphing

realworld.title: Business Break-even Analysis
realworld.description: The intersection point of cost and revenue lines shows the break-even point where profit is zero

realworld.title: Mobile Plans Comparison
realworld.description: Graphing different mobile plans helps visualize at what usage one plan becomes more economical than another

notes.title: Method Overview
points: Solve one equation for one variable in terms of the other
Substitute this expression into the other equation
Solve the resulting equation for one variable
Substitute back to find the other variable

notes.title: When to Use
points: When one equation is easily solvable for one variable
When coefficients of one variable are 1 or -1
Useful for equations with fractional coefficients

formulas.title: Substitution Steps
formulas.formula: From ax + by = c, express y = (c - ax)/b, then substitute into second equation
formulas.explanation: This method is particularly useful when one equation can be easily solved for one variable

formulas.title: Verification
formulas.formula: Substitute the solution (x, y) back into both original equations to verify
formulas.explanation: Ensures the solution satisfies both equations in the system

realworld.title: Age Problems
realworld.description: Solving problems where one person's age is expressed in terms of another's

realworld.title: Mixture Problems
realworld.description: Determining quantities of different concentration solutions to mix for a desired concentration

notes.title: Method Overview
points: Make the coefficients of one variable equal in both equations
Add or subtract the equations to eliminate one variable
Solve the resulting equation for one variable
Substitute back to find the other variable

notes.title: When to Use
points: When coefficients of one variable are same or additive inverses
When equations can be easily manipulated to create equal coefficients
Particularly useful for integer coefficients

formulas.title: Elimination Formula
formulas.formula: For a₁x + b₁y = c₁ and a₂x + b₂y = c₂, multiply to make coefficients equal and add/subtract
formulas.explanation: Eliminates one variable by creating opposite coefficients

formulas.title: Cross-Multiplication Shortcut
formulas.formula: x/(b₁c₂ - b₂c₁) = y/(c₁a₂ - c₂a₁) = 1/(a₁b₂ - a₂b₁)
formulas.explanation: Direct formula derived from elimination method

realworld.title: Business Profit Analysis
realworld.description: Solving simultaneous equations to find break-even points and profit maximization

realworld.title: Speed-Distance-Time Problems
realworld.description: Calculating speeds of vehicles moving towards or away from each other

notes.title: Method Overview
points: Write equations in standard form: a₁x + b₁y + c₁ = 0 and a₂x + b₂y + c₂ = 0
Use the cross-multiplication formula to find x and y directly
Particularly efficient for solving problems quickly
Derived from the concept of determinants

notes.title: When to Use
points: When coefficients are not easily eliminated by addition/subtraction
For quick solutions in competitive exams
When dealing with fractions and decimals

formulas.title: Cross-Multiplication Formula
formulas.formula: x = (b₁c₂ - b₂c₁)/(a₁b₂ - a₂b₁) and y = (c₁a₂ - c₂a₁)/(a₁b₂ - a₂b₁)
formulas.explanation: Directly gives the solution without needing substitution or elimination steps

formulas.title: Determinant Form
formulas.formula: x = |(b₁ c₁)/(b₂ c₂)| / |(a₁ b₁)/(a₂ b₂)|, y = |(c₁ a₁)/(c₂ a₂)| / |(a₁ b₁)/(a₂ b₂)|
formulas.explanation: Expressed in determinant form, showing relationship with matrix algebra

realworld.title: Chemical Mixtures
realworld.description: Determining quantities of different solutions to mix for desired concentration

realworld.title: Finance Applications
realworld.description: Calculating interest rates and principal amounts in financial planning

realworld.title: Physics Problems
realworld.description: Solving for unknown forces in static equilibrium problems

notes.title: Understanding the Distance Formula
points: The distance between two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂) in a plane is given by: √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²]
Derived from the Pythagorean theorem in right-angled triangles
Can be used to find the length of line segments, sides of polygons, and distances between any two points on a coordinate plane

notes.title: Applications and Properties
points: Used to verify if three points are collinear
Helps in determining the type of triangle (scalene, isosceles, equilateral)
Essential in coordinate geometry proofs and problem-solving

formulas.title: Distance Between Two Points
formulas.formula: Distance = √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²]
formulas.explanation: Calculates the straight-line distance between points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂)

formulas.title: Distance from Origin
formulas.formula: Distance = √(x² + y²)
formulas.explanation: Special case when one point is at the origin (0,0)

realworld.title: Navigation Systems
realworld.description: Used in GPS devices to calculate the shortest distance between current location and destination

realworld.title: Urban Planning
realworld.description: Helps in planning roads and utilities by calculating distances between locations on city maps

notes.title: Internal Division of a Line Segment
points: Finds the coordinates of a point that divides the line segment joining two points in a given ratio m:n
For points A(x₁, y₁) and B(x₂, y₂), the point P(x, y) dividing AB internally in m:n is given by:
x = (mx₂ + nx₁)/(m + n) and y = (my₂ + ny₁)/(m + n)
When m = n, the point is the midpoint of the segment

notes.title: External Division and Midpoint
points: For external division, the formula becomes x = (mx₂ - nx₁)/(m - n) and y = (my₂ - ny₁)/(m - n)
Midpoint formula is a special case when m:n = 1:1
Midpoint M(x, y) = ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2)

formulas.title: Internal Division
formulas.formula: P(x, y) = ((mx₂ + nx₁)/(m + n), (my₂ + ny₁)/(m + n))
formulas.explanation: Finds point P that divides the line joining A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂) internally in ratio m:n

formulas.title: Midpoint Formula
formulas.explanation: Special case of section formula when the ratio is 1:1

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Used to determine the center of mass or balance points in structural designs

realworld.title: Computer Graphics
realworld.description: Essential in scaling, rotating, and transforming images and shapes

notes.title: Using Coordinates
points: The area of a triangle with vertices (x₁, y₁), (x₂, y₂), and (x₃, y₃) is given by:
Area = ½ |x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)|
The absolute value ensures the area is always positive
If the area is zero, the points are collinear

notes.title: Properties and Applications
points: Can be used to check collinearity of three points
Helps in finding the area of any polygon by dividing it into triangles
Useful in coordinate geometry proofs and problem-solving

formulas.title: Area of Triangle Formula
formulas.formula: Area = ½ |x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)|
formulas.explanation: Calculates the area using the coordinates of three vertices

formulas.title: Determinant Form
formulas.formula: Area = ½ |(x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂))|
formulas.explanation: Alternative representation showing the determinant connection

realworld.title: Land Surveying
realworld.description: Used to calculate the area of irregularly shaped plots of land using their GPS coordinates

realworld.title: Computer-Aided Design
realworld.description: Essential in calculating surface areas and volumes in 3D modeling software

realworld.title: Robotics
realworld.description: Helps robots navigate by calculating areas and distances in their environment

notes.title: Fundamental Trigonometric Identities
points: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1 (Pythagorean identity)
1 + tan²θ = sec²θ (Derived from first identity by dividing by cos²θ)
1 + cot²θ = cosec²θ (Derived from first identity by dividing by sin²θ)
These identities are true for all values of θ where the functions are defined

notes.title: Applications and Proofs
points: Used to simplify trigonometric expressions
Essential for solving trigonometric equations
Basis for more advanced trigonometric concepts in higher classes
Widely used in calculus, physics, and engineering

formulas.title: Pythagorean Identity
formulas.formula: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
formulas.explanation: Fundamental identity derived from the unit circle and Pythagorean theorem

formulas.title: Derived Identities
formulas.formula: 1 + tan²θ = sec²θ and 1 + cot²θ = cosec²θ
formulas.explanation: Derived by dividing the fundamental identity by cos²θ and sin²θ respectively

realworld.title: Physics Applications
realworld.description: Used in analyzing wave functions and harmonic motion in physics

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Essential in electrical engineering for analyzing alternating current circuits

notes.title: Complementary Angle Relationships
points: sin(90° - θ) = cosθ and cos(90° - θ) = sinθ
tan(90° - θ) = cotθ and cot(90° - θ) = tanθ
sec(90° - θ) = cosecθ and cosec(90° - θ) = secθ
These relationships help simplify trigonometric expressions and solve problems

notes.title: Applications in Problem Solving
points: Useful in simplifying complex trigonometric expressions
Helps in converting between different trigonometric functions
Essential for solving problems involving angles that add up to 90°

formulas.title: Co-Function Identities
formulas.formula: sin(90° - θ) = cosθ, cos(90° - θ) = sinθ, tan(90° - θ) = cotθ
formulas.explanation: Shows the relationship between trigonometric functions of complementary angles

formulas.title: Reciprocal Relationships
formulas.formula: sec(90° - θ) = cosecθ, cosec(90° - θ) = secθ, cot(90° - θ) = tanθ
formulas.explanation: Demonstrates how co-functions are related through their reciprocals

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Used in calculating angles and dimensions in architectural designs

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: Essential in navigation for calculating bearings and courses

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Uses trigonometric ratios to find heights and distances that are difficult to measure directly
Common terms: Angle of elevation, Angle of depression, Line of sight
Involves creating right-angled triangles to model real-world situations
Uses tangent ratio (opposite/adjacent) frequently for height calculations

notes.title: Problem-Solving Approach
points: Draw a clear diagram representing the situation
Identify known and unknown quantities
Set up the appropriate trigonometric ratio
Solve for the unknown using algebraic manipulation

formulas.title: Basic Trigonometric Ratios
formulas.formula: tanθ = opposite/adjacent, sinθ = opposite/hypotenuse, cosθ = adjacent/hypotenuse
formulas.explanation: Fundamental ratios used in solving height and distance problems

formulas.title: Angle of Elevation/Depression
formulas.formula: Height = Distance × tanθ
formulas.explanation: Used when the angle of elevation or depression and horizontal distance are known

realworld.title: Surveying
realworld.description: Used by surveyors to measure heights of buildings and natural features

realworld.title: Aviation
realworld.description: Pilots use these concepts for calculating descent angles and approach paths

realworld.title: Astronomy
realworld.description: Used to calculate distances to stars and planets using parallax method

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Surface area is the total area that the surface of a three-dimensional object occupies
Measured in square units (cm², m², etc.)
Different formulas for different 3D shapes (cube, cuboid, cylinder, cone, sphere)
Total Surface Area (TSA) includes all faces, while Lateral Surface Area (LSA) excludes top and bottom

notes.title: Key Formulas
points: Cube: TSA = 6a², LSA = 4a² (where 'a' is the side length)
Cuboid: TSA = 2(lb + bh + hl), LSA = 2h(l + b)
Cylinder: TSA = 2πr(r + h), LSA = 2πrh
Cone: TSA = πr(l + r), LSA = πrl (where l = slant height)
Sphere: TSA = 4πr²

formulas.title: Cube Surface Area
formulas.formula: TSA = 6a², LSA = 4a²
formulas.explanation: For a cube with side length 'a'. TSA includes all six faces, LSA includes only the four vertical faces

formulas.title: Cylinder Surface Area
formulas.formula: TSA = 2πr(r + h), LSA = 2πrh
formulas.explanation: For a cylinder with radius 'r' and height 'h'. TSA includes both circular bases and the curved surface

realworld.title: Packaging Industry
realworld.description: Used to calculate the amount of material needed for boxes, cans, and other containers

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Helps in estimating the quantity of paint or plaster required for walls and surfaces

notes.title: Understanding Volume
points: Volume is the space occupied by a three-dimensional object
Measured in cubic units (cm³, m³, etc.)
Different formulas for different 3D shapes
Capacity is often measured in liters (1 liter = 1000 cm³)

notes.title: Key Volume Formulas
points: Cube: V = a³
Cuboid: V = l × b × h
Cylinder: V = πr²h
Cone: V = (1/3)πr²h
Sphere: V = (4/3)πr³
Hemisphere: V = (2/3)πr³

formulas.title: Volume of Prism/Cylinder
formulas.formula: V = Base Area × Height
formulas.explanation: Applies to any prism or cylinder. For cylinder, Base Area = πr²

formulas.title: Volume of Pyramid/Cone
formulas.formula: V = (1/3) × Base Area × Height
formulas.explanation: Applies to any pyramid or cone. For cone, Base Area = πr²

realworld.title: Liquid Storage
realworld.description: Used to determine the capacity of water tanks, fuel tanks, and other storage containers

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Helps in calculating the amount of raw material needed for casting or molding objects

notes.title: Understanding Combined Solids
points: Formed by combining two or more basic 3D shapes
Common combinations: cone on cylinder, hemisphere on cylinder, etc.
Need to consider overlapping or common surfaces when calculating total surface area
Volume of combined solid = Sum of volumes of individual solids

notes.title: Problem-Solving Approach
points: Identify the individual shapes in the combination
Calculate surface areas and volumes of individual parts
Adjust for any common surfaces (subtract overlapping areas)
Add remaining surface areas and volumes as needed

formulas.title: Total Surface Area of Combined Solids
formulas.formula: TSA = Sum of TSA of individual solids - Area of contact surfaces
formulas.explanation: Subtract the area where two solids are joined (if they're in contact)

formulas.title: Volume of Combined Solids
formulas.formula: Total Volume = Sum of volumes of individual solids
formulas.explanation: Volume is additive as long as there's no overlapping space

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Used in designing complex structures with multiple geometric shapes like domes on cylindrical buildings

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Essential for designing and manufacturing machine parts with combined geometric shapes

realworld.title: Packaging
realworld.description: Used to design packaging with multiple compartments or unusual shapes

notes.title: Understanding Mean (Average)
points: Mean is the average value of a dataset
For grouped data, we use the class mark (midpoint) of each class interval
Three methods: Direct Method, Assumed Mean Method, and Step Deviation Method
Most appropriate method depends on the data distribution and class intervals

notes.title: Calculation Methods
points: Direct Method: Mean = Σ(fi × xi)/Σfi, where fi is frequency and xi is class mark
Assumed Mean Method: Mean = A + (Σfidi)/Σfi, where A is assumed mean and di = xi - A
Step Deviation Method: Mean = A + h(Σfiui)/Σfi, where h is class width and ui = (xi - A)/h

formulas.title: Direct Method Formula
formulas.formula: Mean (x̄) = (Σfi × xi) / Σfi
formulas.explanation: Where fi is the frequency of the ith class and xi is the class mark of the ith class

formulas.title: Assumed Mean Method
formulas.formula: Mean (x̄) = A + (Σfidi)/Σfi, where di = xi - A
formulas.explanation: A is the assumed mean, di is the deviation from A, and fi is the frequency

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Used to calculate the average marks of students in a class or school

realworld.title: Business
realworld.description: Helps businesses understand average sales, revenue, or customer spending

notes.title: Understanding Median
points: Median is the middle value that divides the data into two equal parts
For grouped data, we use the median class concept
Cumulative frequency is used to locate the median class
More reliable than mean for skewed distributions

notes.title: Calculation Steps
points: Find the cumulative frequencies
Determine the median class where n/2th observation lies
Use the formula: Median = l + [(n/2 - cf)/f] × h
Where l = lower limit of median class, cf = cumulative frequency of class before median class, f = frequency of median class, h = class width

formulas.title: Median Formula
formulas.formula: Median = l + [(n/2 - cf)/f] × h
formulas.explanation: l = lower limit of median class, n = total frequency, cf = cumulative frequency before median class, f = frequency of median class, h = class width

formulas.title: Finding Median Class
formulas.formula: The class whose cumulative frequency is just greater than n/2
formulas.explanation: Where n is the total number of observations (Σfi)

realworld.title: Real Estate
realworld.description: Used to find the median price of houses in a neighborhood, which is less affected by extreme values than the mean

realworld.title: Income Analysis
realworld.description: Governments use median income to better represent typical earnings than the mean, which can be skewed by very high incomes

notes.title: Understanding Mode
points: Mode is the value that appears most frequently in the data
For grouped data, we use the modal class and a formula to estimate the mode
A distribution can be unimodal, bimodal, or multimodal
Useful for categorical data and identifying most common categories

notes.title: Calculation Method
points: Identify the modal class (class with highest frequency)
Use the formula: Mode = l + [(f1 - f0)/(2f1 - f0 - f2)] × h
Where l = lower limit of modal class, f1 = frequency of modal class, f0 = frequency of class before modal class, f2 = frequency of class after modal class, h = class width

formulas.title: Mode Formula
formulas.explanation: l = lower limit of modal class, f1 = frequency of modal class, f0 = frequency of class before modal class, f2 = frequency of class after modal class, h = class width

formulas.title: Empirical Relationship
formulas.formula: Mode = 3 × Median - 2 × Mean
formulas.explanation: Approximate relationship between mean, median and mode for moderately skewed distributions

realworld.title: Retail
realworld.description: Helps stores identify the most frequently sold items to optimize stock levels

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Used to determine the most common travel times to schedule additional services or staff

realworld.title: Healthcare
realworld.description: Helps identify the most common symptoms or conditions in a population

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Experiment: A process that gives well-defined outcomes (e.g., tossing a coin, rolling a die)
Sample Space (S): Set of all possible outcomes (e.g., S = {H, T} for a coin toss)
Event: Subset of sample space (e.g., getting a head in a coin toss)
Favorable Outcomes: Outcomes that define the event of interest

notes.title: Probability Formula
points: P(E) = Number of favorable outcomes / Total number of possible outcomes
Probability ranges from 0 (impossible event) to 1 (certain event)
Sum of probabilities of all possible outcomes is always 1
P(not E) = 1 - P(E)

formulas.title: Basic Probability
formulas.formula:
P(E) = n(E) / n(S)
where n(E) = number of favorable outcomes
n(S) = total number of possible outcomes
formulas.explanation: Classical definition of probability

formulas.title: Complementary Events
formulas.formula:
P(E) + P(not E) = 1
P(not E) = 1 - P(E)
formulas.explanation: Probability of an event not occurring

realworld.title: Weather Forecasting
realworld.description: Meteorologists use probability to predict rain, storms, etc.

realworld.title: Games and Sports
realworld.description: Understanding probability helps in making strategic decisions in games

notes.title: Types of Problems
points: Coin Toss Problems: Probability of getting heads/tails
Dice Problems: Probability of specific numbers or sums
Card Problems: Probability of drawing specific cards from a deck
Real-life Scenarios: Probability in everyday situations

notes.title: Problem-Solving Approach
points: Identify the sample space
Define the event of interest
Count favorable outcomes
Apply probability formula
Simplify the fraction if possible

formulas.title: Probability of Two Independent Events
formulas.formula:
P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B)
Example: P(Head on first toss and Head on second toss) = 0.5 × 0.5 = 0.25
formulas.explanation: For independent events

formulas.title: Probability of Mutually Exclusive Events
formulas.formula:
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B)
Example: P(1 or 2 on a die) = 1/6 + 1/6 = 1/3
formulas.explanation: For events that cannot occur together

realworld.title: Quality Control
realworld.description: Manufacturers use probability to predict defect rates

realworld.title: Risk Assessment
realworld.description: Insurance companies use probability to calculate premiums

notes.title: First Law (Law of Inertia)
points: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force
Inertia: Property of matter to resist changes in its state of motion
Examples: Passengers jerking backward when a bus starts suddenly, dusting a carpet

notes.title: Second Law (Force and Acceleration)
points: Force equals mass times acceleration (F = ma)
Acceleration is directly proportional to force and inversely proportional to mass
Unit of force: Newton (N) = kg·m/s²
Examples: Pushing a shopping cart, kicking a football

notes.title: Third Law (Action-Reaction)
points: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction
Forces always occur in pairs (action-reaction pairs)
Examples: Rocket propulsion, walking, swimming

formulas.title: Newton's Second Law
formulas.formula:
F = m × a
where:
F = Force (N)
m = mass (kg)
a = acceleration (m/s²)
formulas.explanation: Relates force, mass, and acceleration

formulas.title: Weight Calculation
formulas.formula:
W = m × g
where:
W = Weight (N)
m = mass (kg)
g = acceleration due to gravity (9.8 m/s²)
formulas.explanation: Calculates the force of gravity on an object

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Prevent injury by counteracting inertia during sudden stops

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Understanding forces helps improve techniques in various sports

notes.title: Definition and Calculation
points: Momentum (p) is the product of an object's mass and velocity
Vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction)
SI unit: kg·m/s
p = m × v (momentum = mass × velocity)

notes.title: Impulse
points: Change in momentum of an object
Impulse = Force × Time = m(v - u)
Greater force or longer time increases impulse
Examples: Catching a ball, airbags in cars

formulas.title: Momentum
formulas.formula:
p = m × v
where:
p = momentum (kg·m/s)
m = mass (kg)
v = velocity (m/s)
formulas.explanation: Linear momentum of a moving object

formulas.title: Impulse-Momentum Theorem
formulas.formula:
F × Δt = m × Δv = Δp
where:
F = force (N)
Δt = time interval (s)
Δv = change in velocity (m/s)
Δp = change in momentum (kg·m/s)
formulas.explanation: Relates force and time to change in momentum

realworld.title: Vehicle Safety
realworld.description: Increase impact time to reduce force during collisions

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Moving hands back while catching increases time of impact, reducing force

notes.title: Law of Conservation of Momentum
points: Total momentum of an isolated system remains constant if no external forces act on it
m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂
Applies to both elastic and inelastic collisions
Examples: Rocket propulsion, recoil of a gun

notes.title: Types of Collisions
points: Elastic Collision: Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved
Inelastic Collision: Only momentum is conserved, some kinetic energy is transformed
Perfectly Inelastic: Objects stick together after collision

formulas.title: Conservation of Momentum
formulas.formula:
m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂
where:
m = mass
u = initial velocity
v = final velocity
formulas.explanation: Total momentum before collision equals total momentum after collision

formulas.title: Perfectly Inelastic Collision
formulas.formula:
m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = (m₁ + m₂)v
where v is the common velocity after collision
formulas.explanation: When two objects stick together after collision

realworld.title: Space Exploration
realworld.description: Ejection of gases provides thrust based on momentum conservation

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Analysis of collision forces and safety measures

notes.title: Laws of Reflection
points: First Law: The incident ray, reflected ray, and normal at the point of incidence all lie in the same plane
Second Law: The angle of incidence (i) is always equal to the angle of reflection (r)
Regular vs. Diffuse Reflection: Smooth surfaces show clear reflections (mirrors) while rough surfaces scatter light

notes.title: Image Formation by Plane Mirrors
points: Virtual and erect image
Same size as the object
Image distance equals object distance
Lateral inversion occurs

notes.title: Spherical Mirrors
points: Concave mirror: Reflecting surface is curved inwards
Convex mirror: Reflecting surface is curved outwards
Pole, Center of Curvature, Radius of Curvature, Principal Axis, Focus

formulas.title: Mirror Formula
formulas.formula:
1/f = 1/v + 1/u
where:
f = focal length
v = image distance
u = object distance
formulas.explanation: Relates object distance, image distance, and focal length

formulas.title: Magnification
formulas.formula:
m = -v/u = h'/h
where:
m = magnification
v = image distance
u = object distance
h' = image height
h = object height
formulas.explanation: Determines the size of the image relative to the object

realworld.title: Daily Life
realworld.description: Convex mirrors provide a wider field of view in vehicles

realworld.title: Safety
realworld.description: Used in stores for surveillance and in blind spots

notes.title: Laws of Refraction
points: First Law: Incident ray, refracted ray, and normal at the point of incidence lie in the same plane
Second Law (Snell's Law): n₁sinθ₁ = n₂sinθ₂
Refractive Index: n = c/v (speed of light in vacuum/speed in medium)

notes.title: Total Internal Reflection
points: Occurs when light travels from denser to rarer medium
Angle of incidence > critical angle
Critical angle (c): sin c = n₂/n₁ (n₁ > n₂)

notes.title: Optical Phenomena
points: Twinkling of stars
Mirage formation
Rainbow formation
Apparent depth and real depth

formulas.title: Snell's Law
formulas.formula:
n₁sinθ₁ = n₂sinθ₂
where:
n = refractive index
θ = angle of incidence/refraction
formulas.explanation: Relates angles of incidence and refraction to refractive indices

formulas.title: Refractive Index
formulas.formula:
n = c/v = sin i/sin r
where:
c = speed of light in vacuum
v = speed of light in medium
i = angle of incidence
r = angle of refraction
formulas.explanation: Measures how much light bends when entering a medium

realworld.title: Technology
realworld.description: Use total internal reflection for high-speed data transmission

realworld.title: Nature
realworld.description: High refractive index and total internal reflection create brilliance

notes.title: Types of Lenses
points: Convex (Converging) Lens: Thicker at center, converges light rays
Concave (Diverging) Lens: Thinner at center, diverges light rays
Principal focus, focal length, optical center

notes.title: Image Formation by Lenses
points: Convex lens: Real/inverted or virtual/erect images based on object position
Concave lens: Always forms virtual, erect, and diminished images
Uses of convex and concave lenses

notes.title: Power of a Lens
points: Measure of the degree of convergence/divergence of light
SI unit: Diopter (D)
P = 1/f (f in meters)
Convex lens: Positive power, Concave lens: Negative power

formulas.title: Lens Formula
formulas.formula:
1/f = 1/v - 1/u
where:
f = focal length
v = image distance
u = object distance
formulas.explanation: Relates object distance, image distance, and focal length of a lens

formulas.title: Lensmaker's Formula
formulas.formula:
1/f = (n-1)(1/R₁ - 1/R₂)
where:
n = refractive index of lens material
R₁, R₂ = radii of curvature of lens surfaces
formulas.explanation: Relates focal length to the physical properties of the lens

realworld.title: Vision Correction
realworld.description: Convex lenses correct hypermetropia, concave lenses correct myopia

realworld.title: Photography
realworld.description: Combination of lenses to focus light and create sharp images

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Electric current is the flow of electric charge (electrons) through a conductor
SI unit: Ampere (A)
Conventional current flows from positive to negative terminal
Electron flow is opposite to conventional current

notes.title: Electric Circuit
points: Closed path for electric current to flow
Components: Cell/battery, switch, resistor, ammeter, voltmeter
Series and parallel connections
Symbols of electrical components

notes.title: Potential Difference
points: Work done to move a unit charge between two points
SI unit: Volt (V)
Measured using a voltmeter (connected in parallel)
1 Volt = 1 Joule/Coulomb

formulas.title: Electric Current
formulas.formula:
I = Q/t
where:
I = Current (Ampere)
Q = Charge (Coulomb)
t = Time (seconds)
formulas.explanation: Rate of flow of electric charge

formulas.title: Charge Calculation
formulas.formula:
Q = n × e
where:
Q = Total charge
n = Number of electrons
e = Charge of one electron (1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C)
formulas.explanation: Calculates total charge in terms of electron count

realworld.title: Household Wiring
realworld.description: Understanding current helps in designing safe electrical circuits for homes

realworld.title: Electronics
realworld.description: Proper current management is crucial in electronic devices to prevent damage

notes.title: Statement and Definition
points: At constant temperature, current through a conductor is directly proportional to potential difference across its ends
V ∝ I or V = IR
R is the constant of proportionality called resistance

notes.title: Resistance
points: Opposition to the flow of electric current
SI unit: Ohm (Ω)
Depends on: Material, length, area of cross-section, temperature
Resistivity (ρ): Material property independent of dimensions

notes.title: Factors Affecting Resistance
points: Directly proportional to length (R ∝ l)
Inversely proportional to cross-sectional area (R ∝ 1/A)
Depends on material (resistivity ρ)
R = ρ(l/A)

formulas.title: Ohm's Law
formulas.formula:
V = I × R
where:
V = Potential Difference (Volts)
I = Current (Amperes)
R = Resistance (Ohms)
formulas.explanation: Relates voltage, current, and resistance in a circuit

formulas.title: Resistance of a Conductor
formulas.formula:
R = ρ(l/A)
where:
ρ = Resistivity (Ωm)
l = Length (m)
A = Cross-sectional area (m²)
formulas.explanation: Calculates resistance based on material properties and dimensions

realworld.title: Household Appliances
realworld.description: Electric heaters and toasters use high-resistance wires to produce heat

realworld.title: Electronics
realworld.description: Resistors are used to divide voltage in electronic circuits

notes.title: Electrical Energy
points: Work done by moving charges in an electric circuit
SI unit: Joule (J)
Commercial unit: kilowatt-hour (kWh)

notes.title: Electric Power
points: Rate of doing work or consuming energy
P = VI = I²R = V²/R
SI unit: Watt (W)
Common units: kW (kilowatt), MW (megawatt)

notes.title: Heating Effect of Current
points: Joule's Law: H = I²Rt
Applications: Electric heater, iron, bulb
Fuse: Safety device based on heating effect
Efficiency and energy conservation

formulas.title: Electrical Energy
formulas.formula:
E = VIt = I²Rt = (V²/R)t
where:
E = Energy (Joules)
V = Voltage (Volts)
I = Current (Amperes)
R = Resistance (Ohms)
t = Time (seconds)
formulas.explanation: Calculates energy consumed in an electrical circuit

formulas.title: Electric Power
formulas.formula:
P = VI = I²R = V²/R
where:
P = Power (Watts)
V = Voltage (Volts)
I = Current (Amperes)
R = Resistance (Ohms)
formulas.explanation: Calculates power in an electrical circuit

realworld.title: Home Electricity
realworld.description: Understanding power helps in calculating electricity bills and energy conservation

realworld.title: Energy Efficiency
realworld.description: Appliances are rated based on their power consumption and efficiency

notes.title: Metals, Non-metals, and Metalloids
points: Metals: Shiny, malleable, ductile, good conductors of heat and electricity (e.g., Iron, Copper, Gold)
Non-metals: Dull, brittle, poor conductors (e.g., Oxygen, Carbon, Sulfur)
Metalloids: Properties intermediate between metals and non-metals (e.g., Silicon, Arsenic)

notes.title: Modern Periodic Law
points: Properties of elements are periodic functions of their atomic numbers
Periods (rows) and Groups (columns) in the periodic table
Significance of atomic number in classification

notes.title: Representative Elements
points: s-block: Group 1 (Alkali metals) and Group 2 (Alkaline earth metals)
p-block: Groups 13-18 (includes metals, non-metals, and metalloids)
d-block: Transition metals (Groups 3-12)

formulas.title: Valency Calculation
formulas.formula:
Valency = Number of valence electrons (for elements with 1-4 valence e⁻)
Valency = 8 - Number of valence electrons (for elements with 5-7 valence e⁻)
formulas.explanation: Determines combining capacity of an element

formulas.title: Atomic Size Trend
formulas.formula:
Across a period: Decreases
Down a group: Increases
formulas.explanation: Periodic trend of atomic radii

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Combining metals to create materials with desired properties (e.g., Steel from Iron and Carbon)

realworld.title: Electronics
realworld.description: Metalloids like Silicon are crucial in computer chips and solar cells

notes.title: Modern Periodic Table
points: Developed by Henry Moseley (1913)
18 vertical columns (groups) and 7 horizontal rows (periods)
Representative elements, transition metals, inner transition metals

notes.title: Periodic Properties
points: Atomic size, Ionization energy, Electron affinity, Electronegativity
Metallic and non-metallic character
Valency and oxidation states

notes.title: Significance of Groups
points: Group 1: Alkali Metals (1 valence electron, highly reactive)
Group 17: Halogens (7 valence electrons, highly reactive non-metals)
Group 18: Noble Gases (8 valence electrons, inert)

formulas.title: Ionization Energy
formulas.formula:
X(g) → X⁺(g) + e⁻
(Energy required to remove an electron from gaseous atom)
formulas.explanation: Increases across a period, decreases down a group

formulas.title: Electronegativity
formulas.formula: Tendency to attract shared pair of electrons
formulas.explanation: Fluorine (F) has highest electronegativity (4.0)

realworld.title: Chemical Industry
realworld.description: Periodic trends help predict how elements will react in industrial processes

realworld.title: Medicine
realworld.description: Understanding element properties helps in drug design and development

notes.title: Types of Chemical Bonds
points: Ionic Bond: Transfer of electrons (Metal + Non-metal)
Covalent Bond: Sharing of electrons (Non-metal + Non-metal)
Metallic Bond: Sea of delocalized electrons (Metal + Metal)

notes.title: Ionic Compounds
points: Formed between metals and non-metals
High melting and boiling points
Conduct electricity in molten state or aqueous solution
Examples: NaCl, CaO, MgCl₂

notes.title: Covalent Compounds
points: Formed by sharing of electron pairs
Low melting and boiling points
Poor conductors of electricity
Examples: H₂O, CH₄, CO₂

formulas.title: Ionic Compound Formation
formulas.explanation: Sodium loses 1 electron to achieve stable octet, Chlorine gains 1 electron

formulas.title: Lewis Dot Structure
formulas.formula:
H• + •H → H:H or H-H
(Sharing of 1 pair of electrons in H₂)
formulas.explanation: Represents valence electrons and bonding in molecules

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Ionic compounds like calcium silicate hydrate give strength to concrete

realworld.title: Daily Life
realworld.description: Ionic compounds like alum are used to purify water

notes.title: Carbon's Unique Nature
points: Tetravalency: Forms 4 covalent bonds
Catenation: Ability to form long chains and rings
Allotropy: Exists in different forms (diamond, graphite, fullerene)
Tetrahedral geometry in methane (CH₄)

notes.title: Types of Covalent Bonds
points: Single bond (C-C): Sharing one pair of electrons
Double bond (C=C): Sharing two pairs of electrons
Triple bond (C≡C): Sharing three pairs of electrons

notes.title: Electron Dot Structures
points: Representation of valence electrons
Octet rule and stability
Examples: Methane (CH₄), Ethene (C₂H₄), Ethyne (C₂H₂)

formulas.title: General Formula - Alkanes
formulas.formula:
CₙH₂ₙ₊₂
Example: Methane (CH₄), Ethane (C₂H₆)
formulas.explanation: Saturated hydrocarbons with single bonds

formulas.title: Structural Isomerism
formulas.formula:
Same molecular formula, different structures
Example: Butane (C₄H₁₀) has 2 isomers
formulas.explanation: Compounds with same molecular formula but different structural arrangements

realworld.title: Fuel Industry
realworld.description: Methane (CH₄) is the main component of natural gas used for cooking and heating

realworld.title: Jewelry
realworld.description: Diamond's hardness and brilliance make it valuable in jewelry

notes.title: Classification
points: Alkanes: Single bonds (C-C), saturated (e.g., Methane, Ethane)
Alkenes: At least one double bond (C=C) (e.g., Ethene, Propene)
Alkynes: At least one triple bond (C≡C) (e.g., Ethyne, Propyne)

notes.title: Nomenclature
points: IUPAC naming system
Prefix (number of carbons) + ane/ene/yne suffix
Examples: Methane (1C), Ethene (2C), Propyne (3C)

notes.title: Chemical Properties
points: Combustion: Burning in oxygen to produce CO₂, H₂O, and energy
Substitution reaction (Alkanes)
Addition reaction (Alkenes and Alkynes)
Oxidation reactions

formulas.title: Combustion Reaction
formulas.formula:
CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O + Heat
(Methane combustion)
formulas.explanation: Complete combustion of hydrocarbons produces carbon dioxide and water

formulas.title: Addition Reaction
formulas.formula:
CH₂=CH₂ + H₂ → CH₃-CH₃
(Ethene to Ethane)
formulas.explanation: Hydrogenation reaction adding hydrogen across double bond

realworld.title: Fuel Industry
realworld.description: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) contains propane and butane, used as cooking fuel

realworld.title: Plastics Industry
realworld.description: Ethene (C₂H₄) is the monomer for polyethylene plastic

notes.title: Important Functional Groups
points: Alcohols (-OH): Methanol (CH₃OH), Ethanol (C₂H₅OH)
Carboxylic Acids (-COOH): Methanoic acid (HCOOH), Ethanoic acid (CH₃COOH)
Aldehydes (-CHO): Methanal (HCHO), Ethanal (CH₃CHO)
Ketones (-CO-): Propanone (CH₃COCH₃)

notes.title: Homologous Series
points: Same functional group
Similar chemical properties
Successive members differ by -CH₂- unit
Gradual change in physical properties

notes.title: Chemical Properties
points: Esterification: Alcohol + Acid → Ester + Water
Saponification: Alkaline hydrolysis of esters
Dehydration: Removal of water molecule
Oxidation of alcohols

formulas.title: Esterification
formulas.formula:
R-COOH + R'-OH → R-COO-R' + H₂O
Example: CH₃COOH + C₂H₅OH → CH₃COOC₂H₅ + H₂O
formulas.explanation: Reaction between carboxylic acid and alcohol to form ester

formulas.title: Oxidation of Ethanol
formulas.formula:
C₂H₅OH + [O] → CH₃CHO + H₂O
(Ethanol to Ethanal)
CH₃CHO + [O] → CH₃COOH
(Ethanal to Ethanoic acid)
formulas.explanation: Stepwise oxidation of primary alcohol to aldehyde and then to carboxylic acid

realworld.title: Food Industry
realworld.description: Dilute solution of ethanoic acid (5-8%) used as preservative and flavoring agent

realworld.title: Medical Field
realworld.description: Ethanol (C₂H₅OH) is used as antiseptic and in tinctures

notes.title: Human Digestive System
points: Alimentary canal: Mouth → Pharynx → Esophagus → Stomach → Small intestine → Large intestine → Rectum → Anus
Accessory organs: Salivary glands, Liver, Pancreas
Processes: Ingestion, Digestion, Absorption, Assimilation, Egestion

notes.title: Enzymes and Digestion
points: Mouth: Salivary amylase breaks down starch into maltose
Stomach: Pepsin digests proteins, HCl activates enzymes and kills bacteria
Small Intestine: Complete digestion by pancreatic and intestinal enzymes
Liver: Produces bile for fat emulsification

notes.title: Absorption and Assimilation
points: Villi in small intestine increase surface area for absorption
Glucose and amino acids absorbed into blood capillaries
Fatty acids and glycerol absorbed into lacteals (lymphatic system)
Assimilation of nutrients by body cells

formulas.title: Digestive Enzymes
formulas.formula:
Starch → (Salivary Amylase) → Maltose → (Maltase) → Glucose
Proteins → (Pepsin/Trypsin) → Peptides → (Peptidases) → Amino acids
Fats → (Bile salts) → Emulsified fats → (Lipase) → Fatty acids + Glycerol
formulas.explanation: Breakdown of major food components in human digestion

formulas.title: pH in Digestive System
formulas.formula:
Mouth: ~7 (Neutral)
Stomach: 1.5-3.5 (Acidic)
Small Intestine: ~8 (Alkaline)
formulas.explanation: Optimal pH levels for different digestive enzymes

realworld.title: Nutrition
realworld.description: Understanding digestion helps plan meals with proper nutrients for health

realworld.title: Health
realworld.description: Knowledge of digestion helps understand conditions like ulcers, diarrhea, and constipation

notes.title: Human Respiratory System
points: Pathway: Nostrils → Nasal cavity → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli
Lungs: Spongy, elastic organs in thoracic cavity
Diaphragm: Dome-shaped muscle that aids in breathing

notes.title: Mechanism of Breathing
points: Inhalation: Diaphragm contracts (flattens), ribs move up and out, volume increases, pressure decreases
Exhalation: Diaphragm relaxes (domes up), ribs move down and in, volume decreases, pressure increases
Normal breathing rate: 15-20 times per minute

notes.title: Gas Exchange
points: Occurs in alveoli (air sacs) by diffusion
Oxygen diffuses from alveoli into blood
Carbon dioxide diffuses from blood into alveoli
Role of hemoglobin in oxygen transport

formulas.title: Respiration Equation
formulas.formula:
C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + Energy (ATP)
(Glucose + Oxygen → Carbon dioxide + Water + Energy)
formulas.explanation: Aerobic cellular respiration in mitochondria

formulas.title: Lung Capacity
formulas.formula:
Tidal Volume (TV): ~500ml (normal breathing)
Vital Capacity (VC): TV + IRV + ERV
Total Lung Capacity: VC + Residual Volume
formulas.explanation: Measurements of lung function

realworld.title: Health
realworld.description: Understanding respiration helps prevent and manage conditions like asthma and COPD

realworld.title: Sports Science
realworld.description: Knowledge of respiration helps athletes optimize breathing techniques

notes.title: Human Heart and Blood Vessels
points: Four-chambered heart: 2 atria (receiving) and 2 ventricles (pumping)
Blood vessels: Arteries (carry blood away from heart), Veins (carry blood to heart), Capillaries (exchange sites)
Double circulation: Pulmonary and systemic circuits

notes.title: Blood Composition
points: Plasma (55%): Water, proteins, nutrients, hormones, waste
Red Blood Cells (RBCs): Carry oxygen (hemoglobin)
White Blood Cells (WBCs): Fight infections
Platelets: Blood clotting

notes.title: Cardiac Cycle
points: Sinoatrial (SA) node initiates heartbeat
Atrial systole: Atria contract, blood to ventricles
Ventricular systole: Ventricles contract, blood to arteries
Diastole: Heart chambers relax and fill with blood

formulas.title: Blood Pressure
formulas.formula:
Normal: ~120/80 mmHg
Systolic: Pressure during heart contraction
Diastolic: Pressure during heart relaxation
formulas.explanation: Measures force of blood against artery walls

formulas.title: Cardiac Output
formulas.formula:
Cardiac Output (CO) = Heart Rate (HR) × Stroke Volume (SV)
Average: ~5 L/min at rest
formulas.explanation: Volume of blood pumped by heart per minute

realworld.title: Healthcare
realworld.description: Understanding blood components is crucial for safe blood transfusions

realworld.title: Fitness
realworld.description: Regular exercise strengthens heart and improves circulation

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Heat: Form of energy that flows from hotter to colder objects
Temperature: Measure of hotness or coldness (degree of hotness)
SI unit: Kelvin (K), Common unit: Celsius (°C)
Absolute zero: 0 K = -273.15°C (theoretical minimum temperature)

notes.title: Thermal Equilibrium
points: When two objects are in thermal contact and no heat flows between them
At equilibrium, both objects have the same temperature
Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics: If A=B and B=C, then A=C (thermal equilibrium)

notes.title: Thermometers
points: Liquid-in-glass thermometers (mercury/alcohol)
Clinical thermometers (35°C to 42°C)
Digital thermometers and thermocouples

formulas.title: Temperature Conversion
formulas.explanation: Converting between Kelvin, Celsius, and Fahrenheit scales

formulas.title: Heat Energy
formulas.formula:
Q = mcΔT
where:
Q = Heat energy (J)
m = mass (kg)
c = specific heat capacity (J/kg·K)
ΔT = temperature change (K or °C)
formulas.explanation: Calculates heat energy required to change temperature

realworld.title: Weather
realworld.description: Meteorologists use precise temperature measurements for weather forecasting

realworld.title: Health
realworld.description: Monitoring body temperature helps detect fever and illness

notes.title: Conduction
points: Heat transfer through a medium without actual movement of particles
Occurs in solids (metals are good conductors)
Example: Metal spoon getting hot in hot soup

notes.title: Convection
points: Heat transfer by actual movement of fluid particles
Occurs in fluids (liquids and gases)
Natural and forced convection
Example: Boiling water, sea breeze

notes.title: Radiation
points: Heat transfer through electromagnetic waves
Does not require any medium (can occur in vacuum)
All objects emit thermal radiation
Example: Heat from the sun, thermal cameras

formulas.title: Thermal Conductivity
formulas.formula:
Q/t = kA(ΔT/d)
where:
Q/t = Heat transfer rate (J/s or W)
k = thermal conductivity (W/m·K)
A = cross-sectional area (m²)
ΔT = temperature difference (K)
d = thickness (m)
formulas.explanation: Rate of heat conduction through a material

formulas.title: Stefan-Boltzmann Law
formulas.formula:
P = εσAT⁴
where:
P = power radiated (W)
ε = emissivity (0-1)
σ = Stefan-Boltzmann constant (5.67×10⁻⁸ W/m²K⁴)
A = surface area (m²)
T = absolute temperature (K)
formulas.explanation: Total power radiated by a black body

realworld.title: Household
realworld.description: Different cooking methods utilize different heat transfer methods

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Understanding heat transfer helps design energy-efficient buildings

notes.title: Linear Expansion
points: Change in length with temperature
ΔL = αL₀ΔT
Example: Railway tracks have gaps to allow for expansion

notes.title: Area Expansion
points: Change in area with temperature
ΔA = 2αA₀ΔT
Example: Metal lids on glass jars

notes.title: Volume Expansion
points: Change in volume with temperature
ΔV = γV₀ΔT (γ ≈ 3α)
Anomalous expansion of water (maximum density at 4°C)

formulas.title: Linear Expansion
formulas.formula:
ΔL = αL₀ΔT
where:
ΔL = change in length (m)
α = coefficient of linear expansion (K⁻¹)
L₀ = original length (m)
ΔT = temperature change (K)
formulas.explanation: Calculates change in length due to temperature change

formulas.title: Volume Expansion of Liquids
formulas.formula:
ΔV = βV₀ΔT
where:
β = coefficient of volume expansion (K⁻¹)
β ≈ 3α for solids
formulas.explanation: Calculates change in volume with temperature

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Bridges and buildings have expansion joints to prevent damage from thermal expansion

realworld.title: Household
realworld.description: Liquid-in-glass thermometers work based on thermal expansion of liquids

notes.title: Definition and Concept
points: Amount of heat required to raise temperature of 1 kg of substance by 1 K
SI unit: J/kg·K
Water has high specific heat capacity (4186 J/kg·K)
Metals generally have low specific heat capacity

notes.title: Calorimetry
points: Measurement of heat changes
Principle of calorimetry: Heat lost = Heat gained
Water equivalent of a substance

notes.title: Applications
points: Water as coolant (high specific heat capacity)
Cooking utensils (materials with low specific heat capacity heat up quickly)
Land and sea breezes

formulas.title: Specific Heat Capacity
formulas.formula:
Q = mcΔT
where:
Q = heat energy (J)
m = mass (kg)
c = specific heat capacity (J/kg·K)
ΔT = temperature change (K)
formulas.explanation: Relates heat energy to temperature change

formulas.title: Calorimetry Principle
formulas.formula:
m₁c₁(T₁ - T) = m₂c₂(T - T₂)
where:
T = final equilibrium temperature
formulas.explanation: Heat lost by hot body = Heat gained by cold body

realworld.title: Climate
realworld.description: Water's high specific heat capacity moderates coastal temperatures

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Water is used in car radiators and industrial cooling systems due to its high specific heat capacity

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Work is done when a force causes displacement in its own direction
Work = Force × Displacement × cosθ
Unit: Joule (J) = N·m
Work is a scalar quantity

notes.title: Types of Work
points: Positive work: Force and displacement in same direction
Negative work: Force and displacement in opposite directions
Zero work: When force is perpendicular to displacement

formulas.title: Work Done
formulas.formula: W = F·s·cosθ
formulas.explanation: W = work (J), F = force (N), s = displacement (m), θ = angle between force and displacement

realworld.title: Everyday Life
realworld.description: Work is done against gravity when lifting objects

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Calculating work helps design efficient machines

notes.title: Definition and Characteristics
points: Energy possessed by a moving object
Depends on mass and square of velocity
SI unit: Joule (J)
Always positive (scalar quantity)

notes.title: Work-Energy Theorem
points: Work done = Change in kinetic energy
W = ΔK.E. = ½mv² - ½mu²
Applies to both constant and variable forces

formulas.title: Kinetic Energy
formulas.formula: K.E. = ½mv²
formulas.explanation: m = mass (kg), v = velocity (m/s)

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Understanding kinetic energy helps design safer vehicles

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Athletes use kinetic energy principles to improve performance

notes.title: Gravitational Potential Energy
points: Energy due to position/height
P.E. = mgh
Zero reference point can be chosen arbitrarily
Decreases as object falls

notes.title: Elastic Potential Energy
points: Energy stored in stretched/compressed objects
P.E. = ½kx² (for springs)
k = spring constant, x = displacement from natural length

formulas.title: Gravitational P.E.
formulas.formula: P.E. = mgh
formulas.explanation: m = mass (kg), g = acceleration due to gravity (9.8 m/s²), h = height (m)

formulas.title: Elastic P.E.
formulas.formula: P.E. = ½kx²
formulas.explanation: k = spring constant (N/m), x = displacement (m)

realworld.title: Hydropower
realworld.description: Dams use gravitational potential energy of water to generate electricity

realworld.title: Sports Equipment
realworld.description: Bows, trampolines, and pole vaults use elastic potential energy

notes.title: Statement and Implications
points: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted
Total energy in an isolated system remains constant
K.E. + P.E. + Other forms = Constant
Applies to all energy transformations

notes.title: Energy Transformations
points: Mechanical to thermal (friction)
Chemical to electrical (batteries)
Nuclear to thermal (nuclear power plants)

formulas.title: Mechanical Energy Conservation
formulas.formula: K.E.₁ + P.E.₁ = K.E.₂ + P.E.₂
formulas.explanation: In the absence of non-conservative forces

realworld.title: Renewable Energy
realworld.description: Solar panels convert light to electrical energy

realworld.title: Physics Education
realworld.description: Demonstrates continuous conversion between kinetic and potential energy

notes.title: Definition and Concepts
points: Rate of doing work or energy transfer
Power = Work/Time = Energy/Time
SI unit: Watt (W) = J/s
Common multiples: kW, MW, HP (Horsepower)

notes.title: Average vs Instantaneous Power
points: Average power: Total work/Total time
Instantaneous power: Rate at a particular instant
P = F·v (when force and velocity are parallel)

formulas.title: Power
formulas.formula: P = W/t = F·v
formulas.explanation: P = power (W), W = work (J), t = time (s), F = force (N), v = velocity (m/s)

formulas.title: Horsepower
formulas.explanation: Conversion between horsepower and watts

realworld.title: Automotive Industry
realworld.description: Horsepower ratings indicate vehicle performance

realworld.title: Home Appliances
realworld.description: Power ratings help estimate electricity usage and costs

notes.title: Combination Reactions
points: Two or more substances combine to form a single product
A + B → AB
Example: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O (Formation of water)

notes.title: Decomposition Reactions
points: A single compound breaks down into simpler substances
AB → A + B
Types: Thermal, Electrolytic, Photochemical
Example: 2HgO → 2Hg + O₂ (Mercury oxide decomposition)

notes.title: Displacement Reactions
points: More reactive element displaces less reactive element
A + BC → AC + B
Example: Fe + CuSO₄ → FeSO₄ + Cu (Iron displaces copper)

notes.title: Double Displacement Reactions
points: Exchange of ions between two compounds
AB + CD → AD + CB
Example: AgNO₃ + NaCl → AgCl + NaNO₃ (Precipitation reaction)

formulas.title: Activity Series of Metals
formulas.formula: K > Na > Ca > Mg > Al > Zn > Fe > Sn > Pb > Cu > Hg > Ag > Au
formulas.explanation: Metals higher in the series can displace those below them

formulas.title: Precipitation Reaction
formulas.formula:
Pb(NO₃)₂ + 2KI → PbI₂↓ + 2KNO₃
(Yellow precipitate of lead iodide)
formulas.explanation: Formation of an insoluble solid (precipitate) when two solutions are mixed

realworld.title: Industry
realworld.description: N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃ (Ammonia production for fertilizers)

realworld.title: Daily Life
realworld.description: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + Energy (Cellular respiration in our bodies)

notes.title: Balancing Chemical Equations
points: Law of Conservation of Mass: Atoms are neither created nor destroyed
Steps: Write unbalanced equation, Balance atoms one by one, Ensure equal number of each atom on both sides
Example: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O

notes.title: Symbols Used in Equations
points: (s) - Solid, (l) - Liquid, (g) - Gas, (aq) - Aqueous solution
↑ - Gas evolved, ↓ - Precipitate formed
Δ - Heat supplied, → - Yields

notes.title: Information from Equations
points: Reactants and products
Physical states of substances
Mole ratios of reactants and products
Energy changes (exothermic/endothermic)

formulas.title: Balancing Example
formulas.formula:
Unbalanced: N₂ + H₂ → NH₃
Balanced: N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃
formulas.explanation: Ensuring equal number of each type of atom on both sides

formulas.title: Mole Concept
formulas.formula:
1 mole = 6.022 × 10²³ particles
= Molar mass in grams
formulas.explanation: Relates mass, number of particles, and volume of gases

realworld.title: Industry
realworld.description: Precise equations ensure correct product formation in industries

realworld.title: Environment
realworld.description: Balanced equations help calculate emissions and air quality

notes.title: Oxidation
points: Addition of oxygen/electronegative element
Removal of hydrogen/electropositive element
Loss of electrons
Increase in oxidation number

notes.title: Reduction
points: Removal of oxygen/electronegative element
Addition of hydrogen/electropositive element
Gain of electrons
Decrease in oxidation number

notes.title: Redox Reactions
points: Oxidation and reduction occur simultaneously
Oxidizing agent gets reduced
Reducing agent gets oxidized
Example: Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu

formulas.title: Oxidation Number Rules
formulas.formula:
Element in free state: 0
Monatomic ion: Equal to its charge
Oxygen: Usually -2 (except in peroxides and OF₂)
Hydrogen: +1 with non-metals, -1 with metals
formulas.explanation: Helps identify oxidation and reduction in reactions

formulas.title: Redox Example
formulas.formula:
Zn⁰ + Cu²⁺SO₄²⁻ → Zn²⁺SO₄²⁻ + Cu⁰
Zn is oxidized (0 to +2)
Cu is reduced (+2 to 0)
formulas.explanation: Zinc loses electrons (oxidized) while copper gains electrons (reduced)

realworld.title: Batteries
realworld.description: Redox reactions generate electrical energy in batteries

realworld.title: Metallurgy
realworld.description: Reduction of metal ores to obtain pure metals

notes.title: Definition and Process
points: Gradual deterioration of metals by chemical or electrochemical reaction with environment
Example: Rusting of iron (formation of hydrated ferric oxide)
4Fe + 3O₂ + xH₂O → 2Fe₂O₃·xH₂O

notes.title: Factors Affecting Corrosion
points: Presence of moisture and oxygen
Presence of electrolytes (salts)
Acidity (pH)
Temperature
Presence of impurities

notes.title: Prevention Methods
points: Galvanization (coating with zinc)
Electroplating (coating with another metal)
Alloying (stainless steel)
Painting/greasing
Sacrificial protection

formulas.title: Rusting of Iron
formulas.formula:
Anode (Oxidation): 2Fe → 2Fe²⁺ + 4e⁻
Cathode (Reduction): O₂ + 2H₂O + 4e⁻ → 4OH⁻
Overall: 2Fe + O₂ + 2H₂O → 2Fe(OH)₂
4Fe(OH)₂ + O₂ + 2H₂O → 4Fe(OH)₃
2Fe(OH)₃ → Fe₂O₃·xH₂O (rust) + (3-x)H₂O
formulas.explanation: Electrochemical process of iron rusting in presence of water and oxygen

realworld.title: Infrastructure
realworld.description: Understanding corrosion helps in protecting steel structures

realworld.title: Automotive
realworld.description: Anti-corrosion treatments extend vehicle lifespan

topics.name: Effects of Oxidation in Daily Life

notes.title: Rancidity
points: Oxidation of fats and oils in food
Results in unpleasant smell and taste
Prevented by: Adding antioxidants, storing in airtight containers, refrigeration, using nitrogen packing

notes.title: Combustion
points: Rapid oxidation of substances with release of heat and light
Examples: Burning of fuels, respiration, burning of candle
CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O + Energy

notes.title: Food Preservation
points: Use of antioxidants (Vitamin C, BHT, BHA)
Vacuum packing
Refrigeration
Use of nitrogen gas in food packaging

formulas.title: Antioxidant Action
formulas.formula:
ROOH + AH → ROH + A• + H₂O
(ROOH = Peroxide, AH = Antioxidant)
formulas.explanation: Antioxidants prevent oxidation by reacting with free radicals

formulas.title: Respiration
formulas.formula: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + Energy (2880 kJ/mol)
formulas.explanation: Controlled oxidation of glucose in living cells

realworld.title: Food Industry
realworld.description: Understanding oxidation helps in food preservation techniques

realworld.title: Health
realworld.description: Foods rich in antioxidants help prevent cell damage in the body

notes.title: Properties of Acids
points: Sour taste (e.g., citric acid in lemons)
Turn blue litmus red
React with metals to produce hydrogen gas
React with carbonates to produce CO₂ gas
Conduct electricity in aqueous solutions

notes.title: Properties of Bases
points: Bitter taste, soapy feel (e.g., soap, baking soda)
Turn red litmus blue
Conduct electricity in solution
React with acids to form salt and water (neutralization)

notes.title: Strength of Acids and Bases
points: Strong acids: Completely ionize in water (HCl, H₂SO₄, HNO₃)
Weak acids: Partially ionize (CH₃COOH, H₂CO₃)
Strong bases: Completely dissociate (NaOH, KOH)
Weak bases: Partially dissociate (NH₄OH)

formulas.title: Neutralization Reaction
formulas.formula: Acid + Base → Salt + Water
formulas.explanation: Example: HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O

formulas.title: Acid-Metal Reaction
formulas.formula:
Acid + Metal → Salt + Hydrogen gas
Example: 2HCl + Zn → ZnCl₂ + H₂↑
formulas.explanation: Reactivity series determines which metals react with acids

realworld.title: Digestive System
realworld.description: Hydrochloric acid (HCl) in stomach aids digestion

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Bases like calcium hydroxide used to neutralize acidic soils

notes.title: Understanding pH
points: Measures acidity or basicity of a solution
Scale ranges from 0 to 14
pH = 7: Neutral (pure water)
pH < 7: Acidic (lower numbers = stronger acid)
pH > 7: Basic/Alkaline (higher numbers = stronger base)

notes.title: pH Indicators
points: Litmus: Red (acid) ↔ Blue (base)
Phenolphthalein: Colorless (acid) ↔ Pink (base)
Methyl orange: Red (acid) ↔ Yellow (base)
Universal indicator: Shows full pH range with color changes

formulas.title: pH Calculation
formulas.formula:
pH = -log₁₀[H⁺]
pOH = -log₁₀[OH⁻]
pH + pOH = 14
formulas.explanation: [H⁺] = hydrogen ion concentration in mol/L

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Measuring soil pH for optimal crop growth

realworld.title: Swimming Pools
realworld.description: Maintaining proper pH for water disinfection and comfort

notes.title: Formation of Salts
points: Neutralization: Acid + Base → Salt + Water
Metal + Acid → Salt + Hydrogen gas
Metal carbonate + Acid → Salt + Water + Carbon dioxide
Metal oxide + Acid → Salt + Water

notes.title: Types of Salts
points: Normal salts: Complete replacement of H⁺ (NaCl, KNO₃)
Acid salts: Partial replacement (NaHSO₄)
Basic salts: Contain hydroxide ions (Pb(OH)NO₃)
Double salts: Two simple salts (K₂SO₄·Al₂(SO₄)₃·24H₂O)

formulas.title: Salt Formation Examples
formulas.formula:
HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O (Neutralization)
H₂SO₄ + 2KOH → K₂SO₄ + 2H₂O
Na₂CO₃ + 2HCl → 2NaCl + H₂O + CO₂
formulas.explanation: Different types of salt formation reactions

realworld.title: Food Industry
realworld.description: Sodium chloride (table salt), sodium bicarbonate (baking soda)

realworld.title: Water Treatment
realworld.description: Using salts to remove calcium and magnesium ions

topics.name: Common Salts Used in Daily Life

notes.title: Sodium Chloride (Common Salt)
points: Chemical formula: NaCl
Uses: Food seasoning, food preservation, chemical industry
Source: Sea water, rock salt deposits

notes.title: Washing Soda
points: Chemical name: Sodium carbonate decahydrate
Formula: Na₂CO₃·10H₂O
Uses: Water softening, glass manufacturing, cleaning agent

notes.title: Baking Soda
points: Chemical name: Sodium hydrogen carbonate
Formula: NaHCO₃
Uses: Baking, antacid, fire extinguisher, cleaning agent

notes.title: Bleaching Powder
points: Chemical name: Calcium oxychloride
Formula: CaOCl₂
Uses: Disinfecting water, bleaching clothes, paper industry

formulas.title: Preparation of Common Salts
formulas.formula:
Washing Soda: NaCl + NH₃ + CO₂ + H₂O → NaHCO₃ + NH₄Cl
Baking Soda: 2NaHCO₃ → Na₂CO₃ + H₂O + CO₂
Bleaching Powder: Ca(OH)₂ + Cl₂ → CaOCl₂ + H₂O
formulas.explanation: Industrial preparation methods

realworld.title: Household Cleaning
realworld.description: Baking soda for deodorizing, washing soda for laundry

realworld.title: Healthcare
realworld.description: Antacids (baking soda), oral rehydration salts

notes.title: Physical Properties
points: Metals: Malleable, ductile, good conductors of heat and electricity, lustrous
Non-Metals: Brittle, poor conductors, dull appearance (except iodine and graphite)
Metalloids: Properties intermediate between metals and non-metals (e.g., silicon, germanium)

notes.title: Chemical Properties
points: Metals: Form basic oxides, lose electrons (oxidize), react with acids to produce H₂ gas
Non-Metals: Form acidic or neutral oxides, gain electrons (reduce), don't react with acids

notes.title: Reactivity Series
points: K > Na > Ca > Mg > Al > Zn > Fe > Sn > Pb > Cu > Hg > Ag > Au
More reactive metals can displace less reactive metals from their compounds

formulas.title: Metal-Acid Reaction
formulas.formula:
Metal + Acid → Salt + Hydrogen
Example: Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂
formulas.explanation: Metals above hydrogen in reactivity series react with acids

formulas.title: Metal-Water Reaction
formulas.formula:
Metal + Water → Metal hydroxide + Hydrogen
Example: 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂
formulas.explanation: Vigorous reaction for highly reactive metals

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Choosing appropriate metals based on properties and reactivity

realworld.title: Jewelry
realworld.description: Using less reactive metals like gold and silver for ornaments

notes.title: Metallurgy Steps
points: Concentration of ore (removal of impurities)
Conversion to oxide (calcination/roasting)
Reduction to metal (using carbon, aluminum, or electrolysis)
Refining (electrolytic refining, zone refining)

notes.title: Extraction Methods
points: Electrolytic reduction (for highly reactive metals like Na, K, Ca)
Reduction with carbon (for medium reactive metals like Zn, Fe, Pb)
Roasting and reduction (for less reactive metals like Cu, Hg)

formulas.title: Extraction of Iron
formulas.formula:
Fe₂O₃ + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO₂ (in blast furnace)
C + O₂ → CO₂
CO₂ + C → 2CO
formulas.explanation: Iron is extracted from hematite in a blast furnace

formulas.title: Extraction of Aluminum
formulas.formula: 2Al₂O₃ → 4Al + 3O₂ (electrolysis in molten cryolite)
formulas.explanation: Hall-Héroult process for aluminum extraction

realworld.title: Mining Industry
realworld.description: Large-scale extraction of economically important metals

realworld.title: Recycling
realworld.description: Recycling metals to reduce environmental impact of mining

notes.title: Corrosion Process
points: Electrochemical process requiring oxygen and moisture
Rusting of iron: 4Fe + 3O₂ + xH₂O → 2Fe₂O₃·xH₂O
Factors affecting: Moisture, electrolytes, pH, temperature, impurities

notes.title: Prevention Methods
points: Barrier protection: Painting, greasing, plastic coating
Sacrificial protection: Using more reactive metals (galvanization)
Alloying: Making stainless steel
Electroplating: Coating with less reactive metals

formulas.title: Rusting Process
formulas.formula:
Anode: 2Fe → 2Fe²⁺ + 4e⁻
Cathode: O₂ + 2H₂O + 4e⁻ → 4OH⁻
Overall: 4Fe + 3O₂ + 2H₂O → 2Fe₂O₃·H₂O
formulas.explanation: Electrochemical reactions during rusting

realworld.title: Infrastructure
realworld.description: Protecting bridges, ships, and buildings from corrosion

realworld.title: Automotive
realworld.description: Using galvanized steel and protective coatings

notes.title: Common Alloys
points: Steel: Fe + C (0.2-2.1%) - Construction, tools, vehicles
Stainless Steel: Fe + Cr + Ni - Cutlery, medical instruments
Brass: Cu + Zn - Musical instruments, decorative items
Bronze: Cu + Sn - Statues, bearings, coins
Duralumin: Al + Cu + Mg + Mn - Aircraft construction

notes.title: Properties and Uses
points: Enhanced strength and hardness compared to pure metals
Improved resistance to corrosion
Lower melting points than pure metals
Specialized properties for specific applications

formulas.title: Alloy Composition Examples
formulas.formula:
Stainless Steel: Fe (73%) + Cr (18%) + Ni (8%) + C (1%)
Duralumin: Al (95%) + Cu (4%) + Mg (0.5%) + Mn (0.5%)
formulas.explanation: Typical compositions of common alloys

realworld.title: Aerospace
realworld.description: Using lightweight, strong alloys like duralumin

realworld.title: Healthcare
realworld.description: Biocompatible alloys for joint replacements and dental work

realworld.title: Electronics
realworld.description: Using conductive alloys with optimal properties

notes.title: Cell Theory
points: All living organisms are composed of cells
Cell is the basic unit of life
New cells arise from pre-existing cells

notes.title: Types of Cells
points: Prokaryotic cells: No nucleus, no membrane-bound organelles (e.g., bacteria)
Eukaryotic cells: True nucleus, membrane-bound organelles (e.g., plant and animal cells)
Plant vs Animal cells: Cell wall, chloroplasts, large vacuole in plant cells

notes.title: Cell Components
points: Plasma membrane: Selectively permeable barrier
Cytoplasm: Jelly-like substance containing organelles
Nucleus: Control center of the cell

formulas.title: Surface Area to Volume Ratio
formulas.formula: Surface Area/Volume ratio decreases as cell size increases
formulas.explanation: Explains why cells are small - higher ratio allows for efficient exchange of materials

realworld.title: Microbiology
realworld.description: Understanding prokaryotic cell structure helps in developing antibiotics

realworld.title: Medicine
realworld.description: Stem cell research for regenerative medicine

notes.title: Membrane-bound Organelles
points: Nucleus: Contains genetic material (DNA)
Mitochondria: Powerhouse (ATP production)
Endoplasmic Reticulum: Protein and lipid synthesis
Golgi Apparatus: Modifies, sorts, and packages proteins
Lysosomes: Digestive enzymes for waste breakdown

notes.title: Non-membrane Organelles
points: Ribosomes: Protein synthesis (free or on RER)
Cytoskeleton: Maintains cell shape and movement
Centrioles: Help in cell division (animal cells only)

notes.title: Plant Cell Specific Organelles
points: Chloroplasts: Site of photosynthesis
Cell wall: Provides structure and support
Central vacuole: Stores water and maintains turgor pressure

formulas.title: Cellular Respiration
formulas.formula: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + 38 ATP
formulas.explanation: Mitochondria convert glucose and oxygen into ATP energy

formulas.title: Photosynthesis
formulas.formula: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + light → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂
formulas.explanation: Chloroplasts convert light energy into chemical energy

realworld.title: Biotechnology
realworld.description: Using knowledge of organelles for genetic engineering

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Enhancing chloroplast function for better crop yields

notes.title: Cell Cycle
points: Interphase: G1 (growth), S (DNA replication), G2 (preparation)
M Phase: Mitosis (nuclear division) and Cytokinesis (cytoplasm division)

notes.title: Mitosis
points: Prophase: Chromatin condenses, nuclear envelope breaks down
Metaphase: Chromosomes align at equator
Anaphase: Sister chromatids separate
Telophase: Nuclear envelopes reform
Cytokinesis: Division of cytoplasm

notes.title: Meiosis
points: Produces gametes (sperm and egg cells)
Two divisions (Meiosis I and II)
Results in four haploid daughter cells
Increases genetic variation through crossing over

formulas.title: Chromosome Number
formulas.formula:
Diploid (2n) → Haploid (n) in meiosis
2n → 2n in mitosis
formulas.explanation: Meiosis reduces chromosome number by half for sexual reproduction

realworld.title: Medical Research
realworld.description: Understanding cell cycle regulation for developing cancer therapies

realworld.title: Genetics
realworld.description: Meiosis explains Mendel's laws of inheritance

realworld.title: Reproductive Medicine
